ost_step.1: Calculate the area available for plants (excluding space around them): $(111 \times 1) - (4 \times 1) = 111 - 4 = 107$ square feet.

direct_answer.text: Firstly calculate the maximum possible number of plants using all free areas as follows : Number of Plants = Available Area / Area Required Per Plant . Hence , it would result into following equation: No Of Plants = \( \frac{107}{2.5} \) This simplifies down to approximately 42.8 . Since you cannot buy fractional part of one whole item such like here used in this scenario i.e., plastic pots containing soil which could potentially harbor bacteria or disease if partially filled hence round off your value to nearest integer thus resulting onto only  42 plants being considered due to not having enough resources to purchase additional quantity. And finally multiply no_of_plants by price_per_plant calculated earlier to get overall expenditure made towards purchasing these newly acquired species namely ; Cost_Of_New_Plants\_Buying=$6\times{}42$.Thus Total Amount Spent By Buying New Additions:$252$Dollars

0.user_question: Pat has a flower bed that is 111 feet long.  Pat wants to fill her flower bed with plants.  Pat's flowers grow 12 inches wide so she needs to leave 1.5 feet between every plant.  Pat already owns 4718637 flowers.  Each flowering plant costs $6 at the store,  how much money will Pat spend at the store to fill up her flower bed?

1.subquestion: Let x be number of spaces available to place new plants (every space counts). Then what equation relates all quantities together ?

subanswer.text: To calculate the spaces needed for the existing plants without counting their width since they don't affect spacing calculations directly, let y represent these non-space occupied lengths. Considering an average length per plant includes its growth plus gaps required; hence, the combined length taken by one set including both used plants area and gap equals the individual plant size times itself plus the interval distance i.e., ((inches converted) × sqrt(pi))²+((gap_length infeet)(inch conversion factor)), resulting in approximately 0.3 ft². This leads us to formulate our relation based on subtracted garden usage from capacity leaving room enough for additional ones using Eqn.(A): \(y+(x \times (\sqrt{0.3})^2)+(\frac{1}{12} \times  4718637)=111\). Hence Equation (B), representing free areas considering current occupants alongside newly added potential plots takes shape thusly \(\frac{1}{12}(4718637)=\frac{(111-(y\times (0.3)^2)}{\sqrt {0.3}}\). These relations allow solving for unknown 'x', revealing quantity possible placements within constraint boundaries ultimately deductible values determining actual purchases accordingly.
